Chapter 14: Distinguishing the Noble Ones, part 6, section 14. What is the reason that all arhats who have separated from the defilements of the peak of existence do not accept rebirth?
However, among them, there are those who have realized the state of non-arising of the afflictions, but not all of them.
Some say it is because there are differences in faculties.

This explanation is unreasonable, because the scriptures say that those with the nature of retrogression and non-retrogression are the same in terms of faculties. As it is said, because the five faculties are extremely superior, sharp, and perfect, they are called liberated by both parts.
However, there are those liberated by both parts who have the nature of retrogression, so it is not because of the superiority of faculties that the afflictions are not realized as non-arising.
If that is so, then why is it that the six types of nature are only found in the fruits of the saints, and not in others?
The cultivation and training of faculties is only in the stage of post-learning, but it is also found in other stages.
Verse:
Learners and ordinary beings also have six types, but not through the path of insight.
The treatise says:

Learners and ordinary beings also have six types of dispositions, because the six types of results are preceded by them. Due to the distinction of the dispositions in which they abide, there is either subsequent birth or non-birth of the severing of afflictions.
At what time is the non-arising of the severed afflictions realized?
It is said that when one attains the superior path that can stop this type of affliction,
then this non-arising should be cessation through discrimination, not non-cessation through discrimination.
If it is non-cessation through discrimination, then non-cessation through discrimination should be the fruit of the path, and this would contradict the holy teachings.
As it is said:
What are non-fruit dharmas?
They are non-cessation through discrimination and space.

There is no error in making this non-arising into cessation through discrimination, because the superior path transforms, not for this [non-cessation through discrimination], and since it is not what is to be done, it is not the fruit of the path.

That is, the superior path is turned into the realization of cessation through discrimination, not cessation not due to discrimination. Therefore, when the path is turned, the non-arising that is realized is not called the fruit of the path.

It is like the case of lighting a lamp, which is originally done to dispel darkness, not to consume oil. When the lamp is lit, it not only dispels darkness but also consumes the oil. However, the consumption of the oil is not what was originally intended, so it is not called the fruit of lighting the lamp.
This should be the same, so there is no error.
Therefore, when the superior lineage and superior path arise, non-arising is also realized, but it is not the fruit of the path.

Now, it is analyzed that the non-arising realized by the path is definitely not due to the faculties, because all should be able to attain it. It is only attained by the power of the superior lineage, so for the unshakable one, afflictions will definitely not arise.

Previously it was said that there are three types of non-returners who regress to the state of learner: one who advances faculties, one who regresses and abides as a learner, and one who abides in their own stage and attains parinirvÄá¹‡a.

The four of thought and so on have four, five, six, and seven, respectively. Not only those beyond training can perfect their faculties. Those in training and ordinary beings also have this meaning. Only those in the path of insight can cultivate and perfect their faculties. In this state, they cannot give rise to added effort.

That is to say, the state of the path of insight quickly moves forward and does not have the leisure to cultivate other matters in it. Only in the state of faith and understanding and in the state of ordinary beings can one cultivate and perfect oneâ€™s faculties, as in the state beyond training.
As it is said that the unshakable one does not regress and enjoys the present dharma, how is it that the unshakable one is also said to regress?
There is no error in this.
Why is this?
The verse states:
It should be known that there are three kinds of regression: already obtained, not yet obtained, and enjoyment.
The Buddha has only the last, the sharp one has the last two, and the dull one has all three.
The treatise says:
It should be known that there are three kinds of regression in general. The first is regression of what has been obtained, which refers to regressing from the superior merits that have been obtained.
The second is regression of what has not been obtained, which refers to not yet being able to obtain the merits that should be obtained.
The third is the degeneration of enjoyment, which is the non-manifestation of the superior qualities that have already been attained.
Among the three, the first two have non-acquisition as their substance, and the third is only their non-manifestation.

Among these three degenerations, the World-Honored One has only the degeneration of enjoyment, because there is a definite task to be done that draws his mind, and although there are innumerable rare and uncommon Buddha-dharmas, there is no opportunity for them to arise.
Except for the World-Honored Buddha, the immovable Dharma has both the degeneration of what has not yet been attained and the degeneration of enjoyment.
This means that the superior qualities such as the attainment of the meditation of non-conflict have not yet been attained, so there is the degeneration of what has not yet been attained;
there are other tasks that draw the mind, and there is no opportunity for the qualities that have already been attained to arise, so there is the degeneration of enjoyment.
The other five types of nature may all have the three, because they may also retrogress from the qualities that have already been attained.
In terms of the degeneration of enjoyment, it is said that the immovable Dharma retrogresses from the present enjoyment of the Dharma, but there is no contradiction.
The author of the treatise says this:
If you take the position that there is no regression, you should not raise this objection.
How can one who does not regress be one who enjoys the present Dharma?
This is not because of regression or nonregression from the trance states.
The scriptures say that the dharmas of regression and nonregression are all called the unshakable liberation of pure liberation of all perfected beings.
However, there are those who regress in the mastery of the trance states and are called those who regress, and those who do not regress are called those who do not regress.
The same is true of the other three types of perfected beings, such as those who contemplate.
If this is so, then what is the difference between those who do not regress, those who are steadfast, and those who are unshakable?
All of them are those who do not lose mastery of the trance states.

Those who do not regress are not those who have attained this mastery through the exercise of the faculties, while those who are unshakable are those who have attained it through the exercise of the faculties. The superior trance states produced by these two types of perfected beings do not regress even when they encounter conditions that cause regression.
Those who are steadfast only do not lose the superior virtues they have already attained, but they are unable to induce the arising of other superior virtues.

Even if they generate it, they can fall away from it. This is the difference between the three kinds of arhats, those who do not fall away, etc. But this classification of arhats as falling away, etc., is not established.
We reply, you have already been refuted in various ways in our previous arguments. The three kinds of arhats, those who do not fall away, etc., are mixed up with each other.

We reply, according to your doctrine, there is no difference between the two kinds of arhats, those who do not fall away and those who are steadfast, because both are not obtained through the exercise of the faculties, because both have already obtained superior qualities and do not fall away from them, and because both are able to generate superior qualities that have not yet been obtained.

Even though it is said that those who are steadfast generate new superior qualities and can fall away from them, this is different from those who do not fall away, still, the name steadfast is not established on the basis of this, because the name steadfast is a designation for one who is free from falling away and progress.
Moreover, your school admits that those who are steadfast are of keen faculties. How can you say that they fall away and generate new superior qualities?
If you admit that they fall away, they should be called those who fall away.
In their system, those who are liable to retrogress do not retrogress completely, because if they did retrogress completely, they would generate the passions.

The explanation that those who are unshakable are obtained through the exercise of faculties is also unreasonable, because according to their system, one exercises ones faculties in order to fearlessly enjoy the bliss of samÄdhi in this life. Are the faculties obtained through exercise liable to retrogress or not?
If you admit that they retrogress, they should be called those who retrogress, because they themselves say that those who retrogress from mastery of samÄdhi are called those who retrogress.

If you admit that they do not retrogress, then just as one is called one who retrogresses because of the power of retrogressing, so one would be called one who does not retrogress because of the power of not retrogressing.
In that case, the unshakable would be the same as those who do not retrogress, so how can you insist on establishing a difference between them?

If you say that those who are by nature sharp faculties are called those who do not retrogress, and those who later exercise their faculties and become sharp are called those of unshakable nature, and the two names are established in order to show this difference,ğŸ”½then this is not so.

Then they would be the same as those who are steadfast and capable of penetrating insight, because they admit that those who are steadfast are by nature sharp faculties, not faculties attained through practice, because they are the same in not retrogressing.

Even though it is said that they do not retrogress and are able to newly arouse superior merits that are different from those of the steadfast, this is not reasonable, because nonretrogressing is not established on the basis of newly aroused superior merits.

That is, according to their doctrines, whether or not this nature newly arouses superior merits, it is sharp by nature, and it does not lose mastery over the bliss of the present state of existence. This is the characteristic of nonretrogressing.
The steadfast are also like this, and therefore there should be no difference.

translated: Because they are capable of penetrating insight, they are called capable of penetrating insight. Their doctrines do not say that from this nature one goes to another class of pure liberation. It must be admitted that they are able to practice the cultivation of the impure faculties. They are definitely based on the former nature of retrogressing. The practice of cultivating the faculties is called capable of penetrating insight. This means that the capable of penetrating insight also perfects the faculties through cultivation.

If one admits that one can retrogress from this fruit, then one should call it the family of those who retrogress. If one does not retrogress from it, then one should call it the family of those who are unshakable. Because one who has cultivated the faculties and attained this fruit does not retrogress.

Also, one should not say that one who cultivates the impure faculties and attains the ultimate state is called one of the family of those who are unshakable, because this family of those who are unshakable is the nature of the fruit of arhatship. The teaching and principle of the path to the holy fruits, only the correct principle of the Abhidharma can be relied upon to understand the distinctions of the arhat's retrogressing, etc.

That is to say, based on the pure qualities accomplished in the body of the fruit of arhatship, there are differences in superiority and inferiority, establishing six kinds of distinctions in families.

The arhats who have attained the superior and increased pure qualities must make great efforts to cultivate the training of the faculties, and it is reasonable that they would experience great hardship. But it is not the case that they would experience great hardship for the sake of the inferior qualities that are like a rotting corpse, which are easily destroyed and difficult to accomplish, and which are only temporarily manifested. If arhats are allowed to retrogress from their fruits, do they take rebirth again?
When they retrogress and die with passions, they should be reborn again.
Do they do what they did not do when they were abiding in the fruit?
Since they arouse passions, they should again do what is contrary to the characteristics of the fruit.
There is no such error.
Why is this?
The verse says:
Those who retrogress from the fruit will certainly not die before they regain it.
They do not do what they did not do when abiding in the fruit, because it is temporarily increased.
The treatise says:
Those who retrogress from the fruit will certainly not die in the intermediate state, because if they retrogress, they will certainly regain it in a short time.
If oneâ€™s life span is about to end, there is no possibility of regression, because one has no forgetfulness.
Only when one has a remaining life span is there a possibility of regression. After regression, one will certainly realize it again before long.
As a scripture says:

Bhiká¹£us, you should know that a Å›rÄvaka disciple of the Buddha who has heard much in this way, when he loses right mindfulness, quickly regains it, and causes that which he has lost to be exhausted, submerged, and eliminated.
If it were not so, then the fruit of cultivating pure conduct would not be a place of peace and trust.

Also, one in the state of abiding in the fruit would not do the kind of deeds that violate the fruit. Because of the temporary increase, even though one temporarily loses mindfulness and the active defilements occur, like when abiding in the fruit, there is certainly no principle of doing.
It is like a member of the nobility who temporarily loses his position, but is not equal to an ordinary person in doing base and lowly deeds.
Also, who has regression and who does not have regression?

One who cultivates the contemplation of impurity and enters the holy path may have loss, but one who cultivates the mindfulness of holding the breath and enters the holy path certainly does not have regression.
The arhat who reveres samÄdhi and views does not increase greed and delusion, and so does not retrogress.
In what realm and in what destiny is there retrogressing?

There is retrogressing only in the realm of desire, in the three continents. There is no retrogressing among the six classes of gods of the realm of desire. Some say that there is no retrogressing among those of sharp faculty, because they are able to control their minds and enter the holy path, turning their backs on the excellent objects of desire.
Some say that those who retrogress do so because they lack the conditions for support or because their bodies are not equal.

The two conditions are absent among the six classes of gods of the realm of desire. Even though there are those of dull faculties who are by nature followers of faith, there is no reason for retrogressing after being born there and attaining the holy paths.
Those who retrogress, do they retrogress through the appearance of passions or do the passions appear only after retrogressing?
Some say that one retrogresses through the appearance of passions. How can this be reconciled with the Pâ€™in lei tsa lun?
That treatise says,

The latent tendency of desire for sensual pleasure arises from three things: the latent tendency of desire for sensual pleasure has not yet been eliminated and thoroughly known, things that are the basis for the bonds of desire for sensual pleasure are present, and improper attention is being applied to them. The text continues at length in this vein.
There is no contradiction in this explanation.
Why is this?

The manifestation of the passions is of two kinds, because there is a distinction between those that have already been eliminated and those that have not. The above explanation is given only with reference to those that have not yet been eliminated.

Also, the arising of the passions is of two kinds, because they arise in immediate succession to defiled and undefiled minds. The above explanation is given only with reference to those that arise in immediate succession to a defiled mind.

Or, the arising of the passions is said to be due to three conditions, but the conditions on which the arising of the passions depends are not fixed. Sometimes they arise by the power of the object alone, sometimes by the power of the object and seeds, and sometimes by the power of the object, seeds, and added effort. The above explanation is given with reference to the case where all three are present.

Or, when the passions arise, the three conditions are necessarily present, because improper attention is present and in operation, and the latent tendencies that have been eliminated are necessarily present as seeds.
What kind of mind is immediately followed by the arising of passions and the falling away from a stage?

If one who is without outflows produces the passions of the realm of form or the formless realm and falls away from the stage, he does only so immediately after a good mind associated with the samÄdhi of the class of falling away of his own stage. He does not do so when a mind of neither-restraint-nor-nonrestraint of a higher stage in the realm of desire is present, with the exception of the mind of the fruit of the non-ÄrÅ«pya absorptions. However, there is no falling away from that mind.

Is it not the case that the samÄdhi of the class of falling away is abandoned when one becomes free from the passions of his own stage? How can one who is without outflows have the passions arise and not fall away?
It is really as you say that that mind is present.
However, the class of samÄdhi of abiding has three varieties: that which is conducive to falling away, that which is conducive to progress, and that which preserves its own stage.

The previous statement that the samÄdhi of the class of falling away of oneâ€™s own stage means that the samÄdhi of the class of abiding that is conducive to falling away is a small part of the samÄdhi of abiding. Because it is conducive to a small amount of falling away, it is given the name of falling away.
However, this samÄdhi mind is often associated with the preservation of its own stage and is therefore categorized as the samÄdhi of abiding.

If one has not yet lost the faculty of being able to retrogress, then immediately after that mind, the present passions appear. If one abandons that mind, one is included in the category of abiding in accordance with the present state. If one is slightly inclined to retrogress, one retrogresses through the arising of passions. Therefore there is no contradiction in the text.

If one retrogresses and loses the good mind of the realm of desire through the arising of the bonds of that realm, then both the good mind and the unobscured-non-defined mind of that realm can appear immediately after.

When one who has retrograded from the state of training through the arising of passions, retrogresses from the passions of the realm of form or of the formless realm, if he has previously been completely detached from the passions of that stage, then only the good mind associated with the samÄdhi of being able to retrogress of that stage can appear immediately after;
if he has not been completely detached from the passions of that stage, then both the good mind and the defiled mind of that stage can appear immediately after.

If one retrogresses and loses through the arising of the bonds of the realm of desire, if he has previously been completely detached from the passions of the realm of desire, then both the good mind and the unobscured-non-defined mind of that realm can appear immediately after;

If one has not completely eliminated the defilements of the desire realm, then after the three minds of good, defiled, and non-obscuring-non-defined of the desire realm, all are able to appear.ğŸ”½If one has not yet attained the pure meditative absorptions and formless attainments, then one definitely cannot give rise to the bonds of the form and formless realms and lose what has been attained. Because those delusions arise immediately after those [absorptions and formless attainments], one only gives rise to the bonds of the desire realm and loses what has been attained.

If one has attained the pure meditative absorptions through direct realization, but has not yet attained the pure formless attainments through direct realization, then one definitely cannot give rise to the bonds of the formless realm and lose what has been attained. One may give rise to the bonds of the desire and form realms and lose what has been attained.

If one has already attained the pure meditative absorptions and formless attainments through direct realization, then one may give rise to the bonds of the desire, form, and formless realms and lose what has been attained.

When one loses what has been previously attained, if one gives rise to the bonds of the upper realms and regresses through direct realization, one does not lose the good [roots] of the lower [realms] and does not form the delusions of the lower [realms].

If one gives rise to the bonds of the lower realms and regresses through direct realization, one definitely loses the good [roots] of the upper [realms] and definitely forms the delusions of the upper [realms].
There is another opinion that one must first fall away and then, later, when the object is present, the passions are manifested. How would you interpret the SÅ«tra on the Grasping of Karmic Rewards?
That text says,
When the three bonds of the formless realm are manifested, one falls away from the formless realm and remains in the state of the end of form.
How would you interpret the SÅ«tra on the Skandhas?
That text says,

When a defiled mind of the formless realm is manifested, one abandons good of the class of learners and continues in good of the class of learners. One falls away from the mind of the post-learner and remains in the mind of the learner.
These two texts are not contradictory because they are spoken with reference to the time of awakening.
That is, although one has fallen away, one does not yet know it. When one later generates a passion, one then becomes aware of the fall.

It is like the case of someone who has previously recited the four Ä€gamas but later, after a lapse of a long time, has forgotten them and does not know it. When he later recites them and is unable to do so, he then becomes aware of his forgetting.
This is also to be explained in the same way, and there is no disagreement.
In what state of mind does one fall away and then generate the passions?

When one is in the realm of desire, in a non-defiled and non-defined mind of deportment, craftsmanship, or retribution, one can only give rise to passions after having fallen away from the wholesome mind.

However, this mind of the realm of desire that is non-defiled and non-defined either generally opposes the passions of the three realms, and when this mind is present, there is no falling away and obtaining of the passions of the three realms.
Or it only opposes the passions of desire and form, and when this mind is present, there is falling away and obtaining of the passions of the formless realm.
Or it only opposes the passions of the realm of desire, and when this mind is present, there is falling away and obtaining of the passions of the two realms.
Or it does not oppose the passions of the three realms, and when this mind is present, there is falling away and obtaining of the passions of the three realms.
All minds that give rise to passions after falling away, in accordance with what is appropriate, are as explained above.
Between these two explanations, the former is better.

As mentioned above, there is the attainment of the faculties through cultivation. Now we should consider how many uninterrupted paths and how many paths of liberation there are for the noble ones who cultivate the faculties.
Are they cultivated by contaminated or uncontaminated paths?
On what body and on what stage do they depend?
Verse:
In the stage of no-more-learning, there are nine uninterrupted and liberated paths for each [faculty].
Because of long practice, learners have one [path]. The uncontaminated [paths] depend on three [realms].
No-more-learners depend on nine stages, learners only on six.
Because one abandons the fruit and superior fruit paths, one only obtains the fruit and path [paths].
Discussion:

Those who seek a superior spiritual lineage and cultivate the training of faculties, in the stage of no-more-learning, transforming each spiritual lineage, each have nine uninterrupted and nine liberated paths, like attaining the fruit of arhatship.
Why is this?
Because the nature of dull faculties is long-practiced and not possible to transform with little effort, because it is firmly established by the paths of learners and no-more-learners.
In the stage of learners, transforming each spiritual lineage, each has one uninterrupted and one liberated path, like attaining the first fruit, because it is not long-practiced.
The preparatory path for each stage is one.

When those in the stages of learning and no learning cultivate the faculties in order to sharpen them, they all gradually cultivate the subsequent natures of the faculties, and only after obtaining the superior natures of the faculties do they abandon the previous inferior ones.

Therefore, when those in the stage of no learning cultivate the faculties in order to sharpen them, the preparatory, uninterrupted, and first eight liberations are all included in the category of the faculty of weakness, etc., and the ninth liberation is the faculty of reflection, etc.

When those in the stage of learning cultivate the faculties in order to sharpen them, the preparatory and uninterrupted paths are included in the category of the faculty of weakness, etc., but at the time of the path of liberation they are called the faculty of reflection, etc.

All the great masters from whom I have received the teachings say that the cultivation of the faculties is all for the purpose of preventing the manifestation of the non-obscuring indeterminate ignorance that is elicited by the power of the delusions eliminated by the path of insight and the path of cultivation. Therefore, those in the stage of learning who cultivate the faculties in order to sharpen them are truly for the purpose of preventing the manifestation of the delusions eliminated by the path of insight, and those in the stage of no learning who cultivate the faculties in order to sharpen them are truly for the purpose of preventing the manifestation of the delusions eliminated by the path of cultivation.
As is the case with the many or few uninterrupted paths and paths of liberation that are produced when one eliminates the delusions that elicit them, so is it with the cultivation of the faculties.

The number of times the path is cultivated in order to eliminate the actual form of ignorance that is generated by the seeds of the two kinds of passions is the same as the number of times the path is cultivated to eliminate the seeds of the two kinds of passions. Therefore, the post-learner cultivates nine uninterrupted paths and nine liberated paths in the perfecting of the faculties. The learner perfects the faculties by means of one uninterrupted path and one liberated path.

However, the actual form of ignorance generated by the passions of the realm of form and the formless realm is divided into many classes according to the differences in the obstacles. Therefore, when one transforms the faculty of being able to retrogress, etc., and perfects the faculty of being able to progress, etc., the various paths are present and each eliminates a part. Consequently, there is no case of skipping over a superior class of faculties.
Other masters say that
all perfecting of the faculties is accomplished by means of one preparatory path, one uninterrupted path, and one liberated path.
The former explanation is correct, because the principle is as explained above.

These uninterrupted paths and liberated paths are all categorized as pure paths, because it is not reasonable that the noble person perfects the faculties by means of a worldly path, because the substance of a worldly path is not superior and is not capable.
All preparatory paths are of both kinds. The above discussion is based on the actual practice of the path, but if we add the future cultivation, there are differences.

In the state of post-learner, when cultivating the training of faculties, the preparatory path in the future also cultivates both. The nine uninterrupted paths and eight liberations, what is cultivated in the future, are also only pure. The ninth liberation cultivates both in the future, and also cultivates the merits of the three realms, because it is the same as what is cultivated by the first knowledge of extinction.

If in the state of learner, when cultivating the training of faculties, the preparatory path in the future also cultivates both, the uninterrupted path and liberation in the future what is cultivated is also only pure, like attaining the first fruit.
If so, isn't there a contradiction with the extensive treatise?
As the extensive treatise says:
When attaining the state of seeing by cultivating the training of faculties from the nature of faith and understanding, at that time one also attains the fourteen transformed minds.
Why not allow that in the path of liberation of the learner, one also cultivates the contaminated path in the future?
This is not a mistake.
Why is this?
That treatise only explains what is attained simultaneously, like when the lower ground path is present, the transformed mind of the upper ground is also said to be attained.

That is, if one who has already been freed from the impurity of the three trances enters the path of insight in reliance on the first trance, it is said that he obtains the mind of transformation of the four trances.

However, it is not reasonable that one cultivates the dharmas of the upper stages because the lower path of insight is present. The text merely says that one obtains the mind of transformation of the four trances because it arises simultaneously with the path of insight. This is also the case.
Other masters say:
Because future dharmas have the attainment of attainment, they are said to be cultivated. Since one obtains them simultaneously, why not cultivate them?
Therefore, when learners cultivate the practice of perfecting the faculties, they also cultivate the impure in the path of liberation, but not all can cultivate them in common.

That is, if a srota-Äpanna has not yet advanced to the next fruit and is practicing the practice of perfecting the faculties, in the path of liberation he only cultivates the pure, just as when he obtained the fruit, because the path of insight obtains the fruit of saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin and anÄgÄmin, and when one has not yet advanced to the next fruit, it should be understood in the same way.
When one is separated from the peak of existence and in the middle one perfects the faculties, what is cultivated in the path of liberation is also only pure.
The rest of the learners who cultivate the sharp faculties have both kinds of liberation.
The former explanation is good.
Why is this?
It is not that all who obtain something are said to cultivate it, lest all dharmas be able to cultivate all.

Also, when the learner cultivates the sharp faculties, he is truly able to block the arising of the views that are the passions. Since the number of paths that eliminate the views that are the passions is the same as before, how can the cultivation of the fruit of the path of insight be different?
If one cultivates the impure during the path of liberation of the sharp faculties after the other destinies, why not admit that it is the same in the state of the uninterrupted path?

It is because the two paths are the same as when one is free from the passions.ğŸ”½However, when the post-learner cultivates the sharp faculties, the number of paths cultivated is the same as when one eliminates the peak of existence.
If the learner cultivates the sharp faculties, the number of paths cultivated is the same as when one eliminates the upper realms.

That which is eliminated by the path of insight is similar to the path of the seeker that is obtained at the time of the fruit, because it is only similar to the path of the seeker that is obtained at the time of the fruit.
When the seeker and post-learner cultivate the sharp faculties, the added effort is both that which is obtained and that which is not obtained.
The uninterrupted and liberated paths are only of the present, and all are of the three times.

The knowledge of dharmas and the knowledge of species of those who cultivate the sharp faculties are only in the three continents of humans, because only in these bodies is there fear of falling back.
Why is it called the cultivation of the sharp faculties?
Because it disciplines and cultivates the faculties, causing them to increase and grow.

That is to say, by the power of the path, it causes the continuity of the faculties to abandon the inferior and obtain the middling, and to abandon the middling and obtain the superior, gradually increasing in excellence. This is called the cultivation of the sharp faculties. Therefore, the term cultivation of the sharp faculties refers to the meaning of the transformation of the faculties.

Although the eight liberations gradually obtain the sharp faculties, because of the original mind seeking the superior nature, the superior nature is not yet obtained and the previous inferior is not abandoned, just as the previous stage of the path of seeing is not abandoned upon obtaining the subsequent fruit.

Just as there are six types of seeds in the holy stage that can cultivate the sharp faculties, it should be known that it is also like this in the preparatory stages of heat, etc. before the path of seeing.
The difference is that if in the holy stage one obtains the superior type of seed, one necessarily abandons the previous inferior one;

When one cultivates the faculties in the stages of heat, etc., one only obtains the superior nature, and the inferior nature does not function. This is called the transformation of the faculties, not the abandonment of the inferior and acquisition of the superior.

The transformation of the faculties in the stage of post-learner is based on nine stages, namely the four meditations, the preliminary stage, the intermediate stage, and the three formless realms. Only these nine stages have the pure path, because the other stages do not have it.
The transformation of the faculties in the stage of pre-learner is based only on six stages, excluding the three formless realms.
Why is this?
Because one who transforms the faculties may abandon the fruit and the superior path, and what one obtains is only the fruit, not the superior path, because the mind delights in the fruit.
There is no fruit of the pre-learner that is included in the formless realm, therefore the transformation of the faculties by the pre-learner is based only on six stages.
Even if it is allowed that in the stage of pre-learner, one transforms the faculties based on the formless realm, it is definitely the stage of abiding in the superior path of the fruit.

There is no fruit of the non-returner that is included in the formless realm, therefore one does not transform the faculties and attain the fruit based on the formless realm. This is because the first two fruits are only included in the preliminary stage, and the non-returner is only generally included in the six stages.
Some say that only the fruit of the stage of post-learner is cultivated through the sharpening of faculties, because one should not abandon much and obtain little.

When they reach the stage of no training, they are again given new names, namely, those liberated regardless of occasion and those liberated only when occasion arises.

These two kinds of saints are given different names according to the path, but there is no difference in substance.
The above-mentioned pudgalas are analyzed according to differences in faculties, natures, paths, degrees of freedom from passions, and other factors, and the number of thousands is reached.

The fifteen types are distinguished according to the path, i.e., the eight patiences and the seven cognitions.
